messageBody:
I am not sure that I grok what you are saying.

>My guess would be philosophy. (That DOES sound like a song title, doesn't
>it? :-)

By the hair band eXtreme Programming ?

>If you can only test your class by testing the output it generates on a
>filesystem, its design could be improved. It should probably take an
>OutputStream and write there. You can then compare the contents of the
>OutputStream to your expected result.

As a concrete example I am currently working on a a templated code generator
implemented
as a Javadoc DocLet. So I run Javadoc , giving it the classname of the
doclet and the name
of the code template, and the doclet takes the supplied class information
from Javadoc and produces
an output file according to the template's instructions. It is a simple
program, using the reflection
API and the doclet API to do most of the work.

Most of the 9 classes can be quickly and cleanly unit tested with little
work. But the overall
transformation from Template to generated code also needs to be unit
testable for refactoring
and maintainence reasons.

As far as I can tell, I need a standard "oracular" or dummy doclet
information provider
to act as the source of class information and a standard template to test as
well as
a piece of transformed output to verify against.

The template and canonical output could be embedded as strings in the
program itself.
But the transformed text (going out via a PrintWriter class) I believe is
only accessible
as a file.Am I wrong ? Can I restructure this so that it is unit testable
writing to and
from buffers and still manageable as a file output type of tool ?

>It's all about keeping implementation details out of the public interface.
A
>file representation is an implementation detail - a stream is not.

>One of the benefits you reap if you implement your classes that way is that
>you can add MD5 checksums, compression, etc without any redesign. If your
>class is writing directly to a file, you would have to modify that class to
>achieve the same.

>Of course, that's only a guess - I could be completely off :-)

I think it is clear from my question above that I lack an understanding of
how
this would be achieved within the Javba I/O library.

Awaiting your response with baited breath

Jim JM
